org.dejave.attica.engine.operators
Class Operator

java.lang.Object
  org.dejave.attica.engine.operators.Operator
Direct Known Subclasses:
BinaryOperator, SourceOperator, UnaryOperator
public abstract class Operator
extends java.lang.Object

Operator: The basic operator abstraction. It implements all the plubming for subsequent concrete operators. It is more general than it need be, in the sense that it handles multi-input operators (when in reality most operators will be unary or binary) and is capable of producing multiple outputs with a single call. This can be confusing at times, but, when extending it, it makes it much easier to cater more execution models than a standard push/pull one (e.g., symmetric hash join can be easily implemented since there is a way to return multiple outputs per getNext() call.) Luckily, all this is masked to the programmer. The operator itself buffers all multiple possible outputs and returns a single tuple to the caller through a getNext() call.

Author:
sviglas

setup

protected void setup()
              throws EngineException
Some operators might need to perform some initial setting up. This method is a placeholder for those operators. By default it does nothing.

Throws:
EngineException - thrown whenever there is something wrong during setup.

getNext

public Tuple getNext()
              throws EngineException
Wrapper for the multi-output get next method. In all likelyhood, this is the one that will be called throughout, unless the model is to be substantially extended.

Returns:
the next output tuple of this operator.
Throws:
EngineException - whenever the next tuple cannot be retrieved.

cleanup

protected void cleanup()
                throws EngineException
Called to clean up any resources held by the operator. Default implementation does nothing.

Throws:
EngineException - thrown whenever there is something wrong during cleanup.

innerGetNext

protected java.util.List<Tuple> innerGetNext()
                                      throws EngineException
Inner method to fetch the next tuple(s) from this operator. The data flow of the standard implementation is to loop over all non-exhausted inputs, retrieve tuples, process them, and put them in an output list, which will be returned to the caller.

Returns:
the next tuples for this operator.
Throws:
EngineException - thrown whenever there is something wrong with retrieving tuples from this operator.

processTuple

protected java.util.List<Tuple> processTuple(Tuple tuple,
                                             int inStream)
                                      throws EngineException
Processes a single tuple from an operator, producing multiple tuples in the output.

Parameters:
tuple - the tuple to be processed.
inStream - the index of the input operator this tuple belongs to.
Returns:
a list of output tuples.
Throws:
EngineException - whenever there is an error while processing the tuple.

allDone

protected boolean allDone()
Are all the incoming operators done or not?

Returns:
true if all incoming operators are done, false otherwise.

innerProcessTuple

protected abstract java.util.List<Tuple> innerProcessTuple(Tuple tuple,
                                                           int inOp)
                                                    throws EngineException
The inner tuple processing method -- all operators should implement this.

Parameters:
tuple - the tuple to be processed.
inOp - the index of the input operator the tuple to be processed belongs to.
Returns:
the resulting tuples.
Throws:
EngineException - thrown whenever there is something wrong with processing the tuple.
